structural_unit_name.en: Johan Skytte Institute of Political Studies

description.en: The course covers the key political, economic and security issues of the EU-Russia relations against a broad empirical background of official documents and wider public debates. It discusses the actors' identities, history of EU-Russia relations since the collapse of the Soviet Union, institutional frameworks, bilateral as well as multilateral, issues of path-dependence in the lead-up to the 2014 crisis and the main items on the current agenda. The latter include the sanctions, security, memory, trade and energy, and people-to-people contacts. During the seminar sessions, the discussion is organised around contemporary sources representing the controversies that defined the parties' standing and the political outcomes.
description.et: Kursus käsitleb põhilisi poliitilisi, majanduslikke ning julgeolekualalisi probleeme EL-Venemaa suhetes; taustaks on nii ametlikud dokumendid kui ka avalikud debatid. Arutatakse EL ja Venemaa identiteete, nende suhete ajalugu alatest NL lagunemisest, kahe- ja mitmepoolseid institutsioone, 2014. a. kriisi põhjusi ning kaasaegseid küsimusi.

objectives.en: The course provides an overview of the agenda of EU-Russia relations, reviews their history, institutional foundations analyses the key factors shaping the patterns of both high-profile conflict and low-key cooperation.
objectives.et: Kursuse eesmärk on anda ülevaade Euroopa Liidu ja Venemaa poliitilistest- ja majandussuhetest ning analüüsida peamisi faktoreid, mis neid suhteid määravad.

learning_outcomes.en: Upon completing the course, the students will be able to:
1)	understand the key problems defining the agenda of the relations between the EU and Russia;
2)	relate specific issues of EU-Russia relations to main ideological and theoretical paradigms and be able to critically re-assess the origins and background of specific political discourses;
learning_outcomes.et: - oskab seostada EL-Venemaa suhete seisu teoreetiliste paradigmadega ning mõista erinevaid tõlgendusvõimalusi;

learning_outcomes.en: 3)	use most important sources of information and documents in the field of EU-Russia relations;
learning_outcomes.et: - on võimeline kasutama tähtsamaid allikaid ja dokumente EL-Venemaa suhete alal;

learning_outcomes.en: 4)	be able to use this knowledge by participating in an informed and constructive debate on all aspects of EU-Russia relations.
learning_outcomes.et: - oskab hinnata erinevaid normatiivseid aluseid EL-Vene suhete konfliktsuses tulenevalt Euroopa ideest ja tuleviku maailmakorra üle käivatest debattidest.

notes.et: Students in this course are expected to know and follow the University rules regarding plagiarism. Materials explaining what plagiarism is and how to avoid it are posted on the course page in Moodle. Offenders will be punished according to the UT rules; if the fact of plagiarism is confirmed by the Academic Fraud Committee, the perpetrator automatically fails the course.

independent_work.et:
Students are expected to complete compulsory readings before each class.
It is strongly recommended that students follow the current political developments in the EU and Russia, using major international news outlets.

description.et: The test will be held in class and will consist of multiple-choice questions

Each focused workshop aims to analyse a specific question assigned to a small group of students and requiring an in-depth acquaintance with several key texts.  The allocation of points will depend on the quality of the preparations and the smooth running of the workshop, including time management.

The position  paper is a written text that presents and defends an opinion on one of the issues discussed during the course. Students are encouraged to propose their own topics for the position paper; some possible themes will be discussed at the seminars. The instructor will propose a list of optional topics/questions for position papers . Assessment will be based on the relevance of the main argument, its clear presentation and substantiation. The length of each position paper is limited to 1500 words, measured by the word count of the file submitted in Moodle, including textboxes, footnotes and endnotes. Position papers must attribute ideas directly borrowed from other authors by referring to their work; if necessary, hyperlinks can be embedded in the text. 
The position paper must be submitted using the page of the class in Moodle within two weeks after the last class meeting. Individual extensions will be given in exceptional cases (which mostly implies a major emergency).

grade_preconditions.et: Submission of position paper is a precondition for a positive grade.

grade_evaluation.et:
Final grade for the course will be based on the following criteria:
Colloquium                      40 points
Test				                   20 points
Position paper				    40 points

assessment_scale.et: Eristav (A, B, C, D, E, F, mi)
assessment_scale.en: differentiated (A, B, C, D, E, F, not present)

description.et: Introduction. Course overview and requirements
The starting point: the collapse of the Soviet Union and the end of the Cold War
Russia and the EU in the 1990s and the early 2000s: a Blueprint for Partnership
The descending trend: Russia's Decoupling from from the Liberal International Society
Russia’s aggression against Ukraine: EU Responses
Focused workshop 1; What when wrong with European expertise on Russia?
Russia’s (Mal)information Warfare against Europe and Its Allies
Focused workshop 2: Information Disorder ,Propaganda, Information Suppression
Anti-Putin Opposition: Is There an Alternative to Putin’s Anti-European Discourse?
Focused workshop 3: Russian anti-war dissidents in Europe
Russia and the EU in Global Organizations
Focused workshop 4: World Health Organization, International Organization for Migration, International Red Cross, Greenpeace
Estonia’s Russia policy
Focused workshop 5: repercussions of the war for Estonian domestic and security policies
Russia, Europe and the War in Ukraine: an Outlook from the global South
Focused workshop 6: an outlook from South East Asia
